articles.headline: Crisis Is Over at Texas Plant, but Chemical Safety Flaws Remain
articles.snippet: Explosions at a chemical plant near Houston have revealed gaps in emergency response and disclosure rules for the chemical industry nationwide.
articles.abstract: Explosions at a chemical plant near Houston have revealed gaps in emergency response and disclosure rules for the chemical industry nationwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: CROSBY, Tex. — Residents have returned to their homes here in the shadow of the Arkema chemical plant now that the fires at the plant are out and the immediate safety hazard has passed.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss, Hiroko Tabuchi and Henry Fountain

articles.headline: North Korea’s Nuclear Arsenal Threatens China’s Path to Power
articles.snippet: Beijing has made little secret of its goal to replace the United States as the major power in Asia, but North Korea presents a nettlesome challenge.
articles.abstract: Beijing has made little secret of its goal to replace the United States as the major power in Asia, but North Korea presents a nettlesome challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The two men stood together on the reviewing stand in the North Korean capital: a top official in China’s Communist leadership wearing a tailored business suit and a young dictator in a blue jacket buttoned to his chin.

articles.headline: At CNN, Retracted Story Leaves an Elite Reporting Team Bruised
articles.snippet: Created with much fanfare, CNN’s investigative unit was reshaped and its focus narrowed in the wake of a story that led to a retraction and an apology.
articles.abstract: Created with much fanfare, CNN’s investigative unit was reshaped and its focus narrowed in the wake of a story that led to a retraction and an apology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late on a Monday afternoon in June, members of CNN’s elite investigations team were summoned to a fourth-floor room in the network’s glassy headquarters in Midtown Manhattan.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Worried and Frustrated, ‘Dreamers’ Say They Won’t Give Up
articles.snippet: With the Trump administration announcing an end to a program that let them live and work in the United States, many young immigrants expressed renewed insecurity.
articles.abstract: With the Trump administration announcing an end to a program that let them live and work in the United States, many young immigrants expressed renewed insecurity.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Safir Wazed, a graduate student born in Bangladesh and raised in California, struggled to focus on his studies. Evelin Salgado, born in Mexico and raised in Tennessee, was ending plans to buy a house and wondering what would happen to her teaching job.

articles.headline: United Technologies’ Deal for Rockwell Collins Faces Skepticism
articles.snippet: Investors and customers like Boeing and Airbus questioned the benefits of uniting the two big airplane parts makers.
articles.abstract: Investors and customers like Boeing and Airbus questioned the benefits of uniting the two big airplane parts makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buying Rockwell Collins for $23 billion — one of the biggest deals in the history of the aerospace industry, uniting two major manufacturers — was meant to be a crowning achievement for United Technologies.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: After 16 Futile Years, Congress Will Try Again to Legalize ‘Dreamers’
articles.snippet: President Trump gave Congress six months to pass legislation protecting young, undocumented immigrants that lawmakers have not been able to pass for 16 years.
articles.abstract: President Trump gave Congress six months to pass legislation protecting young, undocumented immigrants that lawmakers have not been able to pass for 16 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For 16 years, advocates for legalizing young immigrants brought here illegally by their parents have tried to pass legislation to shield them from deportation. The bill was called the Dream Act, and in Congresses Democratic and Republican, and in the Bush and Obama administrations, whether by stand-alone bill or comprehensive immigration legislation, it failed again and again.
articles.byline: By Yamiche Alcindor and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Intel’s $1.3 Billion Fine in Europe Requires Review, Court Says
articles.snippet: The Court of Justice of the European Union is sending the case back to a lower court, a decision that bodes well for technology companies facing competition inquiries.
articles.abstract: The Court of Justice of the European Union is sending the case back to a lower court, a decision that bodes well for technology companies facing competition inquiries.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The highest court in the European Union ruled on Wednesday that Intel’s $1.3 billion antitrust fine get a second look, a decision that could ease some of the legal pressure that American tech giants face in the region.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Amie Tsang

articles.headline: A Funeral of 2 Friends: C.I.A. Deaths Rise in Secret Afghan War
articles.snippet: The number of C.I.A. deaths in Afghanistan rivals those killed in the Southeast Asia conflicts of nearly a half-century ago.
articles.abstract: The number of C.I.A. deaths in Afghanistan rivals those killed in the Southeast Asia conflicts of nearly a half-century ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a sweltering day earlier this summer, operatives with the Central Intelligence Agency gathered at Arlington National Cemetery to bury two of their own. Brian Ray Hoke and Nathaniel Patrick Delemarre, elite gunslingers who worked for the C.I.A.’s paramilitary force, were laid to rest after a firefight with Islamic State militants near Jalalabad in Afghanistan, close to the border with Pakistan.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Trump Bypasses Republicans to Strike Deal on Debt Limit and Harvey Aid
articles.snippet: The president sided with Democratic leaders in agreeing to extend government funding and raise the debt ceiling until December, setting up a year-end showdown.
articles.abstract: The president sided with Democratic leaders in agreeing to extend government funding and raise the debt ceiling until December, setting up a year-end showdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump struck a deal with Democratic congressional leaders on Wednesday to increase the debt limit and finance the government until mid-December, blindsiding his own Republican allies as he reached across the aisle to resolve a major dispute for the first time since taking office.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Thomas Kaplan and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Silicon Valley’s Politics: Liberal, With One Big Exception
articles.snippet: A new Stanford study found that the nation’s tech elite are extremely liberal on most issues — except when it comes to regulation.
articles.abstract: A new Stanford study found that the nation’s tech elite are extremely liberal on most issues — except when it comes to regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley has long preferred to remain aloof from national politics, but the Trump era has altered that stance.

articles.headline: Stanley Fischer, Fed’s No. 2 Official, Is Stepping Down
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s vice chairman says he will depart in mid-October, leaving just three people on the seven-seat board.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s vice chairman says he will depart in mid-October, leaving just three people on the seven-seat board.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stanley Fischer, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Wednesday that he would resign in mid-October, an unexpected decision that gives President Trump greater leverage over central bank policy.
